The idea of maintaining the present functionality and adding to 
sounds goo=
d. One possible approach to generalization of the node 
inputs & outputs is=
 as follows:

//###########################################################=
#########
#############################
NNode::NodeUniqueInput::NodeUniqueI=
nput(Population::Link* newlink) {
this->incominglink2.push_back(newlink); /=
/ A list of pointers to 
incoming weighted signals from other nodes
this->i=
ncominglink2_innum =3D newlink->out_node_innum; // output # of 
in_node (i.=
e. each node may have multiple unique outputs)
this->activesum_input =3D 0.=
0; // The incoming activity before being 
processed 
this->active_flag_inpu=
t =3D true;
}
//###########################################################=
#########
#############################


//###############################=
#####################################
#############################
NNode::=
NodeUniqueOutput::NodeUniqueOutput(Population::Link* newlink) {
this->outgo=
inglink2.push_back(newlink); // A list of pointers to 
incoming weighted si=
gnals from other nodes
 node may have multiple unique outputs)
this->outgoi=
nglink2_outnum =3D newlink->in_node_outnum; // output # of 
in_node (i.e. e=
ach node may have multiple unique outputs)
}
//############################=
########################################
#############################


--=

<petar_chervenski@...> wrote=

>
> I think that it's best to generalize that. We can keep the existing 
=
> CPPN way of activation and add to it. We can have, say y=3Df(x) 
nodes, 
=
> (x1, y1) =3D f(x, y) nodes, z =3D f(x, y) nodes and so on. It is just 
> =
additional stages of the activation.. I am thinking for a possible 
> imple=
mentation of it right now. 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "K=
enneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > Sure, I agree, nodes that allow =
more than one input source could 
> > potentially allow some pretty nifty t=
hings to happen.  So by all 
> > means we should try different kinds of nod=
es that diverge from 
> > tradition neural networks.  That's part of why I =
made the 
decision 
> to 
> > call these representations CPPNs rather than =
neural networks.  
> > 
> > In fact, the post to which you just replied des=
cribed just such 
an 
> > activation function, i.e. one that takes two argu=
ments and 
converts 
> > their coordinate frame to polar.
> > 
> > ken
> > =

> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@> wrote:
> > >
> > > Ex=
periments and open research problems are strongly shaped by 
the 
> > > fea=
tures of the tools employed. The resulting feasibility of a 
> > useful 
> =
> > solution can become nothing more than a manifestation of the 
> > > lim=
itations of the tool employed. One-In/One-Out nodes are too 
> > > limiting=
 to explore or "experiment" with, to evaluate potential 
> > > alternative =
activation functions. It is like trying to paint a 
> > sunset 
> > > with =
only black paint on a white canvas. You can identify 
primary 
> > > featur=
es, but it leaves much to be desired.
> > > 
> > > Andy Carl
> > > 
> > > 
=
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> 
wrote:
> =
> > >
> > > > Here are my thoughts after reading through this very 
> inter=
esting 
> > > > conversation.
> > > > 
> > > > First, I agree rotation is a=
n important issue for HyperNEAT; 
> > > however, 
> > > > I am confident th=
at is can be dealt with.  It's an 
interesting 
> > open 
> > > > research =
problem.
> > > > 
> > > > In any case, there is an important aspect of this=
 issue that 
we 
> > > > should also be considering.  The problem is not si=
mply to be 
> able 
> > > to 
> > > > perform a rotation. As Jason's posts =
imply (and Peter 
stated), 
> > > > HyperNEAT and CPPNs should technically =
already be able to 
> perform 
> > > > rotations.  And, in fact, they do.  =
When I play with God Mode 
> in 
> > > > genetic art I often find weights t=
hat when adjusted rotate a 
> part 
> > > of 
> > > > the image.  That is n=
ot that unusual (although perhaps not as 
> > usual 
> > > > as we'd like e=
ither).
> > > > 
> > > > However, that kind of rotation actually *isn't* th=
e type we 
> > really 
> > > > need.  The issue is not that a particular sh=
ape should be 
> > possible 
> > > to 
> > > > rotate some arbitrary angle =
by changing some weights. Recall 
> that 
> > > > CPPNs work by laying out =
coordinate frames within which 
higher 
> > > > strucutres are situated.  T=
o create a symmetric coordinate 
> frame 
> > > means
> > > > creating a gr=
adient with *two* sides, both the opposite of 
each 
> > > > other.  That i=
s, symmetry is not created by flipping a 
gradient 
> > > from 
> > > > one=
 side to the other, but rather by having both sides at the 
> > same 
> > >=
 > time.
> > > > 
> > > > Therefore, a rotational coordinate frame should a=
ctually 
> contain 
> > > > something akin to a sinusoidal gradient that sp=
reads around a 
> > > circle 
> > > > rather than along a line. Then, struc=
tures situated within 
its 
> > > > coordinate frame would repeat in a rota=
ted regular pattern, 
> like 
> > > > petals on a flower (that way you get =
rotatonal invariance).  
> > > > 
> > > > Thus what we really want is to be=
 able to feed in a regular 
2D 
> > > > coordinate frame and output another=
 coordinate frame that is 
a 
> > sine 
> > > > wave around a circle in 2D =
as well.  In other words:
> > > > 
> > > > f(x,y)=3Da point in this circula=
r petal-like gradient
> > > > 
> > > > Thus we only need to define a functi=
on like that and make it 
an 
> > > > activation function that takes two di=
stinct inputs.
> > > > 
> > > > However, the problem does remain of where t=
o control the 
period 
> > of 
> > > > repetition around the circle.
> > > =
> 
> > > > Actually, thinking of it now, what we really want is NOT what 
I=
 
> > > just 
> > > > said but rather something a bit different that would =
solve 
the 
> > > > problem I just posed: What we want is a function f(x,y)=
 that 
> > > produces 
> > > > a gradient that starts at 0 on e.g. the x ax=
is and then 
> increases 
> > > up 
> > > > to 1 as you rotate around the o=
rigin to 360 degrees.
> > > > 
> > > > That way, you have a true circular/p=
olar coordinate system.  
> Then 
> > > you 
> > > > can simply run its out=
put into a sine wave, and you get the 
> > > > repetition around the circle=
 that I describe above.  Then the 
> > > > frequency of repetition is contr=
olled very easily by varying 
> the 
> > > > weight leaving the polar funct=
ion and entering the sine wave, 
> > just 
> > > > as in any normal CPPN!
>=
 > > > 
> > > > So I guess my conclusion is we just need a function that 
>=
 converts 
> > > > Cartesian coordinates to a polar angle, and then running=
 its 
> > output 
> > > > into a periodic activation function will give you=
r nice 
> > rotational 
> > > > repetition, which in a neural substrate is =
rotational 
> invariance!
> > > > 
> > > > Hmm...so I think this explains i=
n part how to deal with the 
> > issue, 
> > > > though maybe not 100% (it =
doesn't explain what it means if 
the 
> > > inputs 
> > > > to such a pola=
r conversion function are not the base-level x 
> and 
> > y, 
> > > > but =
I think such cases will actually yield nice localized 
> > > rotational 
> =
> > > effects as well).  
> > > > 
> > > > Sorry for writing out my thought=
s as they come to me in 
stream 
> of 
> > > > consciousness- this is a rar=
e case where I'm thinking of 
ideas 
> as 
> > I 
> > > > write!
> > > > 
>=
 > > > ken
> > > >
